headline: Why is it so dangerous to visit Brancaster shipwreck? - BBC News
context: Image source, John Fielding Aerial Images
People who risk exploring the wreck can find themselves in danger very quickly

annotations.paragraph: BBC News, Norfolk
annotations.reason: This is a location tag and does not contribute to the story.

annotations.paragraph: A decaying shipwreck has been an intriguing sight on the picturesque north Norfolk coast for 80 years.
annotations.reason: This provides background information about the shipwreck's location and age.

annotations.paragraph: But while it may be tempting to explore, the SS Vina becomes a death trap at high tide, as it was in the case of a man last summer.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the specific danger associated with the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: As a coroner calls for greater safety measures, the BBC looks at the wreck's history and why it is not worth risking a closer look.
annotations.reason: This introduces the coroner's call for safety measures and the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: The SS Vina eventually sank after being used as a target practice for the RAF
annotations.reason: Provides historical context about the ship's fate relevant to its current state as a wreck.

annotations.paragraph: Built in Scotland at the end of the 19th Century, the SS Vina started out as a cargo ship running between England's east coast and the Baltic.
annotations.reason: Offers historical background on the ship's origins, not directly related to the danger of visiting the wreck.

annotations.paragraph: Dr Harry Bennett, an associate honorary professor at the University of Plymouth and an expert in World War Two history, said it was "clapped out" as a merchant ship by the start of the conflict.
annotations.reason: Provides expert commentary on the ship's condition before it became a wreck.

annotations.paragraph: By 1940, it was brought to a Norfolk port, filled with concrete and explosives and used as a blockade.
annotations.reason: Explains the ship's role during the war, contributing to understanding its current dangerous state.

annotations.paragraph: "If the German forces ever decided to rock up at Great Yarmouth, she would prevent access," said Dr Bennett.
annotations.reason: Provides context on the ship's intended military use, relevant to its history as a wreck.

annotations.paragraph: "In 1943 or '44, when the threat of invasion had passed, she was requisitioned by the Ministry of War Transport.
annotations.reason: Provides historical context about the ship's requisition during wartime.

annotations.paragraph: "The RAF was preparing for D-Day and they would practise shooting at targets, and bombing off the coast, and that's what she became; she was simply a target.
annotations.reason: Explains the ship's use as a target, relevant to its current dangerous condition.

annotations.paragraph: "She was towed to Brancaster, a remote area where it was much safer for practice as there was less chance of the good citizens of Norfolk being shot in the process.
annotations.reason: Describes why the ship was moved to Brancaster, relevant to its location.

annotations.paragraph: "Eventually, full of holes, she would have sunk."
annotations.reason: Explains the ship's current state, contributing to its danger.

annotations.paragraph: It is now partly submerged off Scolt Head Island and can be reached on foot from Brancaster beach.
annotations.reason: Provides information on the shipwreck's location and accessibility.

annotations.paragraph: The SS Vina - the three black specks to the left - is just off Scolt Head Island
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about the location of the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: Brancaster is known for its seemingly endless stretch of sand, the North Sea a faint glimmer on the horizon at low tide. It draws thousands of visitors in the summer months.
annotations.reason: This is general background information about Brancaster and not directly related to the dangers of the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: The National Trust, which owns the land, has signs at the car park and at all access points to Brancaster beach to warn of the dangers of the tides and going near the wreck.
annotations.reason: This provides relevant information about warnings related to the dangers of visiting the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: At low tide, however, there is nothing preventing anyone walking over to the heavily corroded, sea-worn hulks of metal that once formed the SS Vina - despite it being extremely perilous to do so.
annotations.reason: This directly addresses the danger of visiting the shipwreck at low tide.

annotations.paragraph: As the tide turns, the wreck site floods at a rapid rate, cutting off the means of escape.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about the danger of flooding at the wreck site.

annotations.paragraph: Dr Bennett said the shifting sands, tides, currents and channels were "always on the move" and approaching the wreck was "incredibly dangerous".
annotations.reason: Offers expert commentary on the dangers of the shifting environment around the wreck.

annotations.paragraph: The deceptive beauty of the coastline possibly put holidaymakers, without that local knowledge, at greater risk, he said.
annotations.reason: Highlights the risk to uninformed visitors due to the deceptive nature of the coastline.

annotations.paragraph: "If you are on coast, you have to be careful and know your business, your tides - the water comes in very quickly," he said.
annotations.reason: Provides a general warning about the speed of incoming tides.

annotations.paragraph: "It is not static, and you are just not going to out-pace that incoming tide."
annotations.reason: Reiterates the danger of the fast-moving tide without adding new information.

annotations.paragraph: Last summer, 74-year-old Raymond Mills was taking a closer look at the wreck when the tide came in. He went under the water and drowned.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a specific incident illustrating the dangers of visiting the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: The BBC approached the HM Coastguard and RNLI for a comment.
annotations.reason: This paragraph does not provide new information related to the dangers of the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: Both said information on call-outs to SS Vina was not readily available but urged anyone visiting any tidal area to check tide times.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers advice relevant to the dangers of visiting the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: The four miles (6km) of sandy beach at Brancaster contain low-lying gullies which fill quickly with fast-flowing tidal water
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the geographical features contributing to the danger.

annotations.paragraph: "I don't think people realise how quick the tide comes in; people are not aware of it," said a man from Brancaster, who did not want to be named.
annotations.reason: The quote highlights the danger of the tide, directly relating to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "It's been there since the Second World War and it's been going on [people visiting the wreck] all my life.
annotations.reason: This provides historical context but does not directly address the current danger.

annotations.paragraph: "It's not uncommon. I think all locals would say the same."
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization without specific information about the danger.

annotations.paragraph: Another resident, who also wanted to remain anonymous, said she was wary of drawing attention to the SS Vina.
annotations.reason: This does not provide specific information about the danger.

annotations.paragraph: "There are warning signs in the area," she said.
annotations.reason: This indicates measures taken to warn about the danger, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "One year the wreck is exposed, and the next it is covered in sand and you can't really put a [warning] sign on the wreck."
annotations.reason: This provides information about the changing conditions of the wreck, contributing to the danger.

annotations.paragraph: Aerial photographer John Fielding regularly flies over Brancaster. He said it gave him a safe view of the wreck and a real sense of the inherent risks.
annotations.reason: This provides context about the photographer's perspective and the risks involved.

annotations.paragraph: "When I first heard there was a shipwreck at Scolt Head Island, I thought it was like something out of Robinson Crusoe," he said.
annotations.reason: This is a personal anecdote that does not add to the understanding of the danger.

annotations.paragraph: "From the air, you can see how dangerous it is to approach on foot.
annotations.reason: This highlights the danger of approaching the wreck, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "I have photographed people there. They think they will get back [to the beach] but you can see how the tide comes and cuts them off; the sea comes in behind them."
annotations.reason: This describes a specific danger related to the tides, directly relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Even at low tide, SS Vina is close to shifting bodies of water
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about the physical dangers of visiting the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: Norfolk senior coroner Samantha Goward, who investigated the circumstances of Mr Mills's death, wants the wreck's owner to look at safety and management, to help prevent future tragedies.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses safety concerns and potential preventative measures related to the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: The problem is, it is unclear who is responsible.
annotations.reason: This highlights an issue regarding the management and responsibility for the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: During World War Two, the wreck was owned and managed by the Ministry of War Transport, which no longer exists, but what happened next is a mystery.
annotations.reason: This provides historical context about the ownership of the shipwreck, relevant to the current issue of responsibility.

annotations.paragraph: The Department for Transport is making inquiries and is due to respond to the coroner.
annotations.reason: This paragraph does not provide information directly related to the dangers of visiting the Brancaster shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: Dr Bennett thinks the curious will continue to be drawn to SS Vina; its removal is almost certainly too difficult and expensive to be a serious consideration.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the challenges of removing the shipwreck, indirectly relating to its continued presence and associated dangers.

annotations.paragraph: "There is an interest in the Second World War, the role of the Brancaster estate in D-Day, and people want to engage with it," he added.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains why people are drawn to the shipwreck, which is relevant to understanding the risks they take.

annotations.paragraph: "For some, it's a waymarker on the beach - 'Let's walk to that wreck, then head back again.'
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides insight into why people visit the wreck, which is relevant to the article's focus on the dangers of visiting.

annotations.paragraph: "I don't know why you would want to do that; nothing is worth the risk."
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes the perceived danger of visiting the shipwreck, directly relating to the article's main premise.

annotations.paragraph: "People who blog about it and tweet about it need to make it clear that this is a dangerous part of the world and [it is] an incredibly dangerous thing to do."
annotations.reason: This quote emphasizes the danger of visiting the shipwreck, directly relating to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: In a statement, the National Trust said it "continued to work with our partner organisations to manage visitor safety at Brancaster beach".
annotations.reason: This provides information on efforts to manage safety, relevant to the dangers of visiting the shipwreck.

annotations.paragraph: It added: "We would like to take this opportunity to remind all those visiting the coast to be aware of the power of the water and that tides can quickly change, and to read safety signage, which is present at all access points to the beach."
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers safety advice and context about the dangers of the area.
